subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove and today
I'd like to tell you the story of how I happened, by circumstance, to become
one of the discoverers of the very first
dinosaur footprints ever found in the state of Nevada. This happened in the year 2010.
Imagine - up until that time
no dinosaur prints had been discovered even though in neighboring states, particularly Utah,
abundant prints had been discovered. Now,
I used to live in Las Vegas right at the western edge and only a ten minute drive
from the Red Rock National Conservation Area, a really beautiful place with
world-class hiking and I made a point in those days of trying to get out into the wilderness as
often as I could, sometimes several times a day, even. I had
over the years acquired some hiking buddies and we've been hiking together for many years. Lynne
Nicholson was a professional musician and my friend Gary Smith was a retired FBI agent.
One day we were hiking way up in a very remote and
relatively inaccessible area of what are known as the Calico Hills inside the Red Rock Conservation Area and
took us over an hour to hike through very steep rocky terrain to get to this
particular spot. We were up on a promontory
with a great view and Gary Smith
looked down at our feet and he said, “You know, look at these marks.
Don't they seem to resemble
dinosaur prints?” Sure enough, it kind of seemed like it might be the case. You could almost imagine
that this was once, not
sandstone, but actual wet sand perhaps. Some dinosaur was climbing in this area
and it was very precarious and there was a risk that the dinosaur might fall off and he was grasping on. I
looked and I said, “Yeah, could be, but who knows with all of these rocks and all of the erosion and the
rocks
coming on top of each other and crashing and layers and you can't be sure about anything.” I left it at that.
But, my friend Gary Smith pursued the matter.
He contacted the Bureau of Land Management to see if they could
investigate it for him
and you know what, they ignored him. So, he contacted the group called the Friends of Red Rock
Canyon. They had a
geologist on the staff there, a fellow named Nick Saines. Gary interested Nick Saines in coming up and
viewing it and Nick seemed kind of impressed so he got some
paleontologists involved. On one occasion - I wasn't there that day -
Gary and Lynn and Nick Saines and the
paleontologists all hiked back to this very same spot. And what do you know, the
paleontologists confirmed that these were indeed
real dinosaur prints - the first ever discovered in the state of
Nevada. I'm showing you some of those prints now.
Furthermore, they discovered more dinosaur prints in that area and other unusual
prints of some primeval
arachnids. These prints date back, I believe, about
65 million
years or so.
Now it's been confirmed. If you were to look on
Google under Smith-Nicholson-Mishlove you'd see newspaper articles and even scientific papers
describing the discovery.
I'm very proud that I had the tiniest role in all of this. But frankly, if it wasn't for
Gary Smith's persistence - and I imagine that has something to do with his training as an FBI agent -
it never would have happened at all.
It would still be there undiscovered. Although now, actually, a number of other locations
have turned up and some beautiful dinosaur prints have shown up in the Red Rock Canyon area.
But here's what I'd like to leave you with. I mean, why is this story of any interest to you at all?
It's because I'd like you to think of what are the dinosaur prints that might be in
your life?
What are the things that are sort of there in the back of your mind? Maybe it's really obvious but you're pushing it away.
You're not sure. Maybe it's not important to you right now. But, it could
signify a serious discovery, a
significant discovery if you were to bring it up
into the spotlight of your consciousness, and maybe even act on it.
Is there a dinosaur print in your life waiting for you to discover it?
I'll leave you with that thought. Thank you for being with me.
